title: Country, God or the Girl
text:
Country, God or the Girl is the fourth studio album by <a href="Somali%20Canadians">Somali-Canadian</a> <a href="hip%20hop%20music">hip hop</a> artist <a href="K%27naan">K'naan</a>. It was released worldwide on October 16, 2012.
Background and development.
The album was first announced in February 2012, with a release date of May 1, 2012. Coinciding with the announcement, he confirmed that he has collaborated with <a href="Nas">Nas</a>, <a href="U2">U2</a> lead singer <a href="Bono">Bono</a>, <a href="Keith%20Richards">Keith Richards</a> of <a href="The%20Rolling%20Stones">The Rolling Stones</a>, American hip-hop and electronic artist and producer <a href="will.i.am">will.i.am</a> and Canadian singer-songwriter <a href="Nelly%20Furtado">Nelly Furtado</a>.
Release and promotion.
Singles.
"<a href="Is%20Anybody%20Out%20There">Is Anybody Out There?</a>" was released as the lead single from "<a href="More%20Beautiful%20Than%20Silence">More Beautiful Than Silence</a>". It features vocals from <a href="Nelly%20Furtado">Nelly Furtado</a>. The song was released as a promotional single in the United States in early January, and as a single worldwide on January 24, 2011. The single made its chart debut on the <a href="Canadian%20Hot%20100">Canadian Hot 100</a> at #67, before peaking at #14. It notably topped the New Zealand charts and peaked at #92 on the <a href="Billboard%20magazine">Billboard</a> <a href="Billboard%20Hot%20100">Hot 100</a>.
"Nothing to Lose", featuring American hip-hop artist <a href="Nas">Nas</a>, was released as the second single from "More Beautiful Than Silence" on February 1, 2012.
"<a href="Hurt%20Me%20Tomorrow">Hurt Me Tomorrow</a>" was released as the album's first official single on May 1, 2012, notably the album's original release date. It peaked at #12 on the <a href="Canadian%20Hot%20100">Canadian Hot 100</a> and at #37 on the "<a href="Billboard%20%28magazine%29">Billboard</a>" <a href="Mainstream%20Top%2040%20%28Pop%20Songs%29">40 Pop Songs</a>
Critical reception.
"Country, God or the Girl" received generally positive reviews from music critics. At <a href="Metacritic">Metacritic</a>, which assigns a normalized rating out of 100 to reviews from mainstream critics, the album received an average score of 74, based on 5 reviews, which indicates "generally favorable reviews". K'naan wrote an op-ed criticizing himself and his attempts to make the album more palatable for American audiences.
